block.p: Israel Curbs Palestinian Travel in the West Bank Israel imposed new travel restrictions on Palestinians in the West Bank and suspended contacts with the Palestinian Authority in response to two drive-by shootings that killed three young Israelis and wounded several other people a day earlier. Two stretches of the main north-south artery of the West Bank will now be closed to private Palestinian vehicles.
PAGE A9

Tobacco Case Appeal Denied The Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal of a decision that sharply limited the monetary damages the tobacco industry could be required to pay in the government's suit against it.
PAGE A18
N.L. Series Lives On With Houston one out away from the first pennant in its history, Albert Pujols's three-run homer gave the Cardinals a 5-4 victory and sent their series back to St. Louis.
PAGE D1

Watch Out, Harry Potter Encyclopedia Brown, one of the literary world's best-known children's characters, may be headed to the big screen. Two producers are offering studios a package that includes the movie and merchandising rights and a script.
THE ARTS, PAGE E1

Scrutiny for Chief of Staff With Karl Rove distracted by the C.I.A. leak inquiry, some of the Bush administration's other recent challenges have cast a longer shadow on Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff.
PAGE A24
Refco Files for Bankruptcy Refco Inc., the giant commodities trading house, sold its futures brokerage business to an investor group and filed for bankruptcy protection.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C3
KPMG Tax Case Is Widened Federal prosecutors widened the criminal case against executives at KPMG over the sale of questionable tax shelters, filing charges against 19 defendants.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1
New Anchors for 'Nightline' A lineup of three anchors, Terry Moran, Cynthia McFadden and Martin Bashir, will replace Ted Koppel on ''Nightline,'' ABC announced.
